image_text: Inflow into a reservoir is all of the water that flows into the reservoir. It is measured in cfs, or cubic feet per second, which is the average rate of water flow into the reservoir. One cfs is equal to 7.48 gallons of water flowing each second. During the drought years, from 2010 to 2016, there was very little inflow into the Oroville reservoir.

Outflow from a reservoir is all of the water that flows out of a reservoir. During the drought years, there was also little outflow from the Oroville reservoir because California was hoarding all of the water Oroville could store.
This year, we have had some very big storms and all of that water has been filling up the Oroville reservoir.
The reservoir was nearly full by mid-February.
There are four ways that water can outflow from the reservoir.
The emergency spillway: Used for the first time over the weekend but the hillside began dangerously eroding within a day after taking on releases that peaked at 12,600 cfs.
Main spillway: Damaged February 7, can release up to 150,000 cfs of water but dam operators were releasing about 100,000 cfs in the days after the spillway was damaged.

Edward Hyatt Powerplant: 14,000 cfs can push through the hydroelectric plan at the base of the dam when operational but it was turned off to prevent it from being damaged after the main spillway was damaged.

River outlet: Located lowest in the reservoir, regulates cold-water releases. It had an original capacity of 5,400 cfs but has largely not been used since it was involved in a 2009 accident that infured dam workers. Officials say it can now release up to 2,000 cfs.

Despite the very high accumulation of water in the reservoir, the Oroville reservoir operators did not outflow water because they were accustomed to conserving all water during the drought. Therefore, all of the ways that water can outflow from the reservoir were nearly unequal to the overflowing water during the February storm.
This caused quite a bit of damage.
